stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on UV mapping and texturing a volcano section of the overworld. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to troubleshooting severe performance issues with Blender 4.1, which was ultimately resolved by installing the F64 renderer plugin. He also discussed and showed the recent integration of Luigi into the game, though his final role remains undecided.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans for the overworld to be a large, seamless, dynamically loading area, but will implement it in stages, first connecting the areas without seamless visuals.
development_findings.quote: After your pass is done, I'm going to make this all into one big level that loads dynamically as you walk through it.

development_findings.summary: A major technical hurdle during the stream was Blender 4.1's severe performance degradation, which was solved by installing the community-made F64 renderer plugin at Lilaa's suggestion.
development_findings.quote: Dude, it's actually unreasonable to work with this. What the fuck? I might have to go back to an old Blender version.

development_findings.summary: Luigi has been successfully imported into the game, but his role is undecided. Co-op is the preferred implementation, but it is not confirmed.
development_findings.quote: Co-op confirmed? Well, I'm not 100% sure exactly how Luigi ties into this yet. Co-op would be the coolest option.

development_findings.summary: Kaze estimates the game could be finished by the end of the year. The current ROM size is approximately 59.95 MB, well within the 64 MB target.
development_findings.quote: The game has a good chance of being done by the end of the year.

development_findings.summary: A new quality-of-life feature has been added: a dialog box appears after collecting a star, allowing the player to choose whether to exit the level or remain in it.
development_findings.quote: Do you want to return to the overworld? Stay or leave? If you hit stay, you stay. If you hit leave, it pops you out. Isn't that cool?

development_findings.summary: An obscure bug where Mario's hair disappeared was traced to a 'write all' setting in the Fast64 toolchain that was automatically enabling itself via a project-wide JSON configuration file, causing conflicts.
development_findings.quote: It turns itself on! The option that breaks if you don't have bleed activated turns itself on whenever you open the file.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy for side levels is that they will be small, contained experiences developed very quickly, in contrast to the larger main courses.
development_findings.quote: Well, these side levels, I hope we can make them a little faster. These are going to be, like, small levels. We're probably going to make each one of them in, like, a day or two at most.

development_findings.summary: Kaze states that Course 7 is complete and has been sent out for beta testing, and confirms the game fully works on real N64 hardware.
Kaze has not given any thought to a PAL version of the game, stating it is an 'afterthought' that will be dealt with later.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes successful politics streamers must be intellectually dishonest or unintelligent, as the format punishes changing one's mind, which is a key trait of a smart person.
context_findings.quote: If you're a politics streamer and you ever change your mind on anything, you're going to lose a portion of your audience. So to be a successful politics streamer you have to be completely dead set on all your beliefs... it kind of necessitates that as a politics streamer you're either grifting or stupid.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds the controversial opinion that he prefers targeted advertising, viewing opposition to it as a sign of being weak-willed.
context_findings.quote: If I'm going to have to sit there and watch a fucking ad, at least show me a product I might want to buy. If you are someone who's like, oh, I don't want them to cater ads to my interests, like why? Are you so weak-willed that you think that you're going to buy a garbage project against your best interest just because it's made for you?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a general disinterest and skepticism towards philosophy, finding the concepts he has encountered to be either painfully obvious or, in the case of Kant, delusional.
context_findings.quote: Anytime I read theory like that, I'm just like, yeah, this is the most fucking obvious shit ever. Why do you write a book? This is just obvious, bro.

context_findings.summary: Kaze questions modern economic systems, wondering why massive technological and productivity gains haven't resulted in significantly less work for the average person, speculating it's due to consumption of 'needless bullshit'.
context_findings.quote: The human race now, with all the automation, is probably literally like a thousand times more productive... So how come we don't have like literally 5 minutes of work a day? Doesn't make sense, right?

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering getting a YouTube sponsor for a future 'F3' event to justify the cost of production, specifically paying his editor.
Kaze has a two-week vacation from his day job coming up, which he plans to dedicate to streaming and finishing the game's overworld.
context_findings.quote: I'll be off work. So there might be like a full two weeks of streams. Which would be hype as fuck. We will probably finish the overworld in those two weeks.

biobak.summary: Biobak's complex texture work for the 'dino domain' was mentioned as being impressive but difficult to implement.
Kaze suggests Biobak should also use the new F64 renderer, implying it would benefit the art pipeline.
biobak.quote: Damn, Biobak, maybe you should download this renderer too.

zeina.summary: Zeina appeared briefly in chat; Kaze made a joking, deadpan comment about their relationship when asked about it.
zeina.quote: What's your life without keys? Probably basically the same. We don't really need each other that much.

key_stories.title: The Blender Performance Nightmare
key_stories.summary: Kaze's workflow was halted by severe performance issues in a new Blender version. After resisting at first, he followed community member Lilaa's advice to install a custom renderer plugin, which completely solved the problem and allowed development to continue.
key_stories.challenge: The new version of Blender (4.1) was performing so poorly that it was nearly impossible for Kaze to do any 3D modeling work on the overworld.
key_stories.process: Kaze expressed extreme frustration with Blender's lag. Lilaa, a contributor in the chat, repeatedly urged him to install the F64 renderer plugin. After initial skepticism and jokes, Kaze relented, downloaded the plugin, and installed it.
key_stories.outcome: The F64 renderer plugin dramatically improved performance, making Blender usable again. Kaze acknowledged that Lilaa's persistent advice was correct, showcasing a moment of community-driven problem solving.
key_stories.key_quote: Wait, maybe we have to take back the death threats. Wait, maybe Lilaa was right.

key_stories.title: The Case of the Disappearing Hair
key_stories.summary: Mario's hair vanished from his model due to a bug. Kaze and Lilaa debugged the issue live, tracing it not to a model or code error, but to an obscure, hidden setting in their custom toolchain that was automatically re-enabling itself.
key_stories.challenge: While exporting the Mario model, his hair mysteriously disappeared, threatening to derail progress.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially suspected a recent code change (PR) from Lilaa. Through a back-and-forth debugging session in chat, they investigated the Fast64 tool settings. They discovered that a setting was being reset every time a file was opened, which caused the rendering error.
key_stories.outcome: The issue was an obscure tool setting, 'write all', being automatically enabled by a project-wide configuration file. By manually editing the JSON file to disable this, Kaze fixed the bug, highlighting the complexity of the custom toolchain.
key_stories.key_quote: It turns itself on! The option that breaks if you don't have bleed activated turns itself on whenever you open the file.

key_stories.title: The Luigi Integration
key_stories.summary: Kaze has added Luigi to the game but has not yet decided on his function. While co-op is the ultimate goal, he is also considering making Luigi a secret, non-playable character as a fun alternative if the technical hurdles for multiplayer are too high.
key_stories.challenge: Integrating Luigi into the game and deciding on his gameplay purpose.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported Luigi's model into the project. He openly mused with the chat about what to do with the character, floating co-op as the best-case scenario. Later, a glitch caused Luigi to appear in-game unexpectedly, prompting further discussion about making his presence a mysterious, random event if co-op proves too difficult.
key_stories.outcome: Luigi's model is successfully in the game, but his final role remains an open creative question. The team is considering co-op as the ideal but may fall back on a simpler implementation, like a secret unlock referencing old Nintendo myths.
key_stories.key_quote: Co-op confirmed? Well, I'm not 100% sure exactly how Luigi ties into this yet. Co-op would be the coolest option.

open_questions.context: Kaze has successfully imported Luigi's model but stated, 'I'm not 100% sure exactly how Luigi ties into this yet. Co-op would be the coolest option.'
questions: What are the primary technical or design challenges preventing the confirmation of co-op multiplayer?
If co-op isn't feasible, what are the leading alternative ideas for Luigi's role in the game?
How does the potential for co-op affect level design for courses that are already complete?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to eventually make the overworld 'one big level that loads dynamically as you walk through it,' but will do a simpler, connected pass first.
questions: What technical approach are you considering for a dynamic loading system on N64?
Are there other games, on N64 or otherwise, that you're using as a technical reference for this system?
How do you plan to manage memory and performance on real hardware with this dynamic loading?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned side levels will be made very quickly, 'in, like, a day or two at most,' and gave an example of an oil tanker mission that unlocks a main course.
questions: What is the core design philosophy for these smaller, rapidly developed side levels?
How does the art and music creation process with Biobak and Badub adapt to such a fast turnaround?
How do you decide which ideas become main courses versus side levels?

open_questions.context: When asked about a PAL version, Kaze stated, 'I haven't really given a Pala version any consideration at all so far. For me Pala right now is in the background. That will have to be an afterthought.'
questions: What are the specific technical hurdles you anticipate when creating a PAL version?
What is the rough plan for tackling PAL support once the NTSC version is complete?

open_questions.context: Zeina, the animator and Kaze's spouse, was present in chat but her work was not discussed. Kaze made a brief, joking comment about their relationship.
questions: How do you two navigate the dynamic of being both professional collaborators and spouses?
What has been your favorite piece of animation to work on for the project so far?
How does the feedback process work between you on animation and game design?

open_questions.context: Badub, the composer, was not mentioned at all during this stream.
questions: What is the collaborative process like with Badub for creating the soundtrack?
How do you communicate the intended mood of a level to him?
With a projected 120 tracks, how is the sheer volume of music being managed?
